div3.head:
The naval engagement at Charleston.
further particulars.
div3.p:
The Charleston papers, with an account of the naval fight near there Saturday, came to hand last night.
It was widely rumored in Charleston Friday evening that the iron clads were to go out, but the same report had been heard so often that little attention was paid to it. About 11 o'clock Friday night the Chicora, Capt. Tucker, and the Palmetto State, Captain Rutledge, with Com. Ingraham on board cast loose from the city wharf and went down to Fort Sumter.
Here they laid until the moon (which was shining brightly) went down.
A correspondent, who was on board the Palmetto State, furnishes the Courier with the following account of the affair:

At 4.30 A. M. the Palmetto State crossed the bar, and stood out at sea in the direction of the blockading fleet.
At 5.20 A. M. we came up to the United States steamer Mercedita, and was hailed by the watch on deck, when the following colloquy took place:

Watch — What steamer is that.
Drop your anchor — back — back — and be careful, or you will run into us.
Captain Rutledge--This is the Confederate States steamer Palmetto State.

As the answer was given the Palmetto State, with full steam up, ran into the Mercedita, the bow striking her right about midships and making an entrance of about three feet. At the same time our bow gun was fired with a seven-inch incendiary shell.
We immediately backed out, when the Mercedita hauled down her flag.
They were ordered to send a boat to us, and Lieut. T. Abbott, commanding, came off with a boat's crew and surrendered his vessel in the name of Com. Stollwagon, of the Mercedita, carrying 7 guns and 153 men. He stated that his vessel was in a sinking condition, and begged our officers to relieve them.
A shot had pierced her boiler, which had burst and scalded a large number of men. Lieut. Abbott begged Commodore Ingraham to take the men with him on board the Palmetto State, as in their haste to come to us they had neglected to put in the plug, and their small boat was only kept afloat by the strenuous efforts of the men bailing the boat.
He also staeed that the water in the Mercedita had up to the time of his leaving, already risen as high as the engine floors.

Commodore Ingraham regretted that he could not comply with the request, as he had no room to accommodate them aboard of his vessels, and no small boats or any other means of affording them relief.
Lieut. Abbott then pledged his word of honor for the officers and crew of the Mercedita not to serve in any manner against the Confederate States until regularly exchanged, upon which condition he was sent on board his own vessel.
The Mercedita was taken completely by surprise.
They were roused from their slumbers by the shock, the men not having scarcely time to dress themselves.
Lieut. Abbott and the men with him were nearly destitute of clothing.

The Palmetto State, leaving the Mercedita to her fate, stood out to sea, and engaged several other vessels of the Abolition blockading fleet, occasionally exchanging shots.
The latter, however, fled at-our approach, firing at long distances and leaving us far astern.
One or two shots were exchanged with the United States frigate Powhatan.
The latter, however followed the example of her companions and fled.
Wethen stood northward, towards the Chicora, which at this time was almost surrounded by the enemy's vessels.
At 8 A. M., there being no more of the Abolition fleet in sight, we stood back to the entrance of Beach Channel, having signalled the Chicora to return.
On passing we were saluted by Forts Moultrie, Sumter, and Ripley, and arrived at the wharf in the city a little before 6 P. M.
Another correspondent of the same paper on the Chicora, gives the following account of her performance:

q.p:
The Chicora, Capt. John R. Tucker, commenced action at 5.05.
The Palmetto State engaged an Abolition vessel on the right, while we engaged the one on the left.
As we passed the blockader on the right, the Palmetto State was laying along-side of her. Keeping on our course, we proceeded to within fifty yards of the vessel on the left, and then gave her a shot from our bow gun, the blockade at the time being under full headway.
We rounded to and gave her the full benefit of our broadside guns and after gun. She immediately rang her ball for fire and made signals of distress to the rest of the fleet.
The last seen of her by signal officer Saunders, she was stern down very low in the water, and disappeared very suddenly.
This vessel is supposed to have gone down.
Notwithstanding the Chicora immediately steamed towards her, nothing could be discovered of the vessel.

bibl.n: Another correspondent of the same paper on the Chicora

div3.p:
The Chicora, proceeding farther out to sea, stood Northward and Eastward, and met two vessels apparently coming to the relief of the missing steamer.
We engaged them.
One of them, after firing a few guns, withdrew.
Standing to the Northward, about daybreak, we steamed up to a small side wheel two-masted steamer and endeavored to come to close quarters.
She kept clear of us, driving away as rapidly as possible, not, however, without receiving our compliments and carrying with her four or five of our shots.
Shortly after the steamship Quaker City and another side wheel steamer came gallantly bearing down on the Chicora and commenced firing at long range.
Neither would permit our boat to get within a respectable distance.
Two of our shoes struck the Quaker City, and she left apparently perfectly satisfied, in a crippled condition.
Another side wheel two-masted steamer with walking beams now steamed toward the Chicora coming down on our stern.
Captain Tucker perceiving it, we rounded to and proceeded until within about five hundred yards, when the belligerent steamer also rounded to and gave us both broadsides and a shot from her pivot gun. We fired our forward pivot gun with an incendiary shell, and struck her just forward of her wheel-house, setting her on fire, disabling and stopping her port wheel.
This vessel was fired both fore and aft, and volumes of smoke was observed to issue from every aperture.
As we neared her, she hauled down her flag and made a signal of surrender, but still kept underway with her starboard wheel and changing her direction.
This was just after daybreak.
We succeeded in catching this vessel, but, having surrendered, and the captain supposing her bolters struck and the escaping steam preventing the engineers from going into the engine room to stop her, ordered us not to fire.
She thus made her escape.
After this vessel had got out of our reach to the perfectly safe distance of about three miles, she fired her last rifled gun, regain hoisted her flag and setting all sails, fired her rifled gun repeatedly at us as she left.

The Chicora now engaged six more of the enemy's vessels at one time--three side-wheel steamers and three propellers — all at long range.
Discovering that the flag-boat, Palmetto State had ceased firing and was standing in shore, orders were given to follow her. On our return, we again came across a three-masted bark-rigged vessel, which we engaged, firing our guns as we passed, striking her once or twice.
We then kept on our course to the bar, having sustained no damage in the action nor a single casualty on board.
The last ship mentioned above kept firing at us until we got out of range, and we giving them our return compliments.
One of the blockaders was certainly sunk.
We engaged her at the distance of only one hundred yards, and she settled down with her stern clear under water.

The Chicora anchored in Beach Channel at 8.30 A. M., and arrived at her wharf in the city about 6 o'clock, receiving a salute from all the forts and batteries as she passed on her return.
The number of shots fired by the Chicora during the whole engagement was twenty-seven, mostly incendiary shells.
Showing the condition of the Mercedita, the Mercury gives the statement of the Lieutenant who came to surrender her:

q.p:
The officer in the boat announced himself as Commander Abbott, of the U. S. sloop-of-war Mercedita Capt. Stollwagon, and said that he came to complete the surrender.
He was conducted before Com. Ingraham and Capt. Rutledge, and, upon his pledge, he and the entire crew of the Mercedita were paroled.
He was then ordered back to his vessel, but asked for assistance in behalf of his crew, as their ship was fast sinking.
He reported that when he left her there were two inches of water on the berth deck, and all their boats were useless, as, in the confusion, they had been lowered without putting in the plugs, which are usually removed to let the rain water escape.
Commodore Ingraham replied that he regretted that want of room and the lack of boats precluded the possibility of receiving them.
The boat's crew, as well as the Yankee officer, had evidently made a hasty toilet, being without shoes or stockings, and otherwise dressed in rather scant fashion.
The Mercedita was a new sloop-of-war, of the second class, built only fifteen months ago, and mounting eleven guns.
Abbott said that the explosion of the boiler had scalded many of the crew, and represented the condition of the Mercedita to be in other respects, most pitiable.

div3.p:
The Mercury contains an account of the capture of the United States gunboat Isaac P. Smith, in Stone river, Friday evening. Our artillery was concealed within two hundred yards of the ship — The crew war just eating supper, and the first shot cleared away all their crockery, killed three men, and wounded several more.
The ship was lying off a farm, and all on board entire of an attack, when our batteries opened.
The Mercury says:

q.p:
At the first discharge there was evidently great consternation on the Yankee decks, and one officer cried out, "Great God!
what is this?" The vessel immediately slipped her cable and began a hasty retreat, fighting the battery as the retired.
She threw grape, shot, and shell, with considerable accuracy, but without injuring any of our man. One grape shot struck the gun of company C, leaving its trace longitudinally.
The firing of our battery at this point was rapid and well executed.
The gun boat, in her flight soon came within range of the batteries of Col. Yates, against which she then directed her broadsides.
But the heavy, concentrated fire from John's Island soon terminated the struggle.
Three shots struck the machinery of the steamer, deranging it so that she could no longer proceed.
She then dropped anchor, and her commander unconditionally surrendered the boat and crew, consisting of 11 officers, 165 men, and three negroes.
Col. Yates thereupon ordered the Yankee Lieutenant commanding to send his men ashore in the steamer's boats, for our men bad none wherewith to board her. The surrender was soon consummated, and a detachment of our force, under Captain Harleston, took possession of the prize Isaac P. Smith.
She proved to be a very valuable capture.
She was built in 1861, and carried a fine armament, consisting offer 30 pounded Parrott gun and eight 8 inch. heavy Columbiads.--Her hull and machinery were not materially injured, and will soon be in serviceable condition.

div4.head: The editorial article for which Boileau was arrested
div4.p: --the Proceedings relative to his Arrest.

The arrest of Albert D. Boileau, the publisher and editor of the Philadelphia Evening Journal, for disloyalty, has created more excitement in the East than any arrest yet made by the Washington despot.
A history of the entire proceedings in the affair is given by the Philadelphia correspondent of the New York World, and we extract such portions of it as are interesting.
The following is the editorial for the publication of which Boileau was arrested:

q.p:
The third annual message of Jefferson Davis to the Confederate Congress, and Abraham Lincoln's last message to the United States Congress, provoke a comparison quite damaging to the intellectual capacity of the Federal President.
Dr. Russell, in his "Reminiscences of America" relates that while dining with Mr. Seward, Mr. Lincoln's chief Secretary, the conversation turned upon Jefferson Davis, when, among other things, Mr. Seward remarked that "he (Davis) was the ablest statesman in America, and that the force of his intellect formed the chief sustaining power of the Southern Confederacy." John Ravage thus speaks of him when he occupied the position of United States Senator:

div4.p:
"When Senator Davis arises in the chamber he invariably commands attention.
He is not hazardous in debate; consequently, when he speaks, the conclusion is that he knows what he speaks about.
His manner is easy, and there is a precision in his phraseology which gives a vigor and force to his speeches that accord well with the military character of the speaker.
His language, as well as his manner, is orderly rather than ornate."

John Quincy Adams had a habit of always observing new members.
He would sit near them on the occasion of their congressional debates, closely eyeing and attentively listening, if the speech pleased him, but quickly departing if it did not. When Davis first arose in the House the ex-President took a seat close by. Davis proceeded and Adams did not move.
The one continued speaking and the other listening, and those who know Mr. Adams's habit were fully aware that the new member had deeply impressed him. At the close of the speech, "the old man eloquent" crossed over to some friends and said, "that young man, gentlemen, is no ordinary man. He will make his mark yet, mind me." And that young man has "fulfilled the promise."

Some time ago Mr. Davis went West to inspect and see for himself the condition of the armies and defences of the Confederacy in that quarter.
He was received everywhere along the route by ovations of the people, and made speeches at Murfreesboro', Chattanooga, Knoxville, Vicksburg, Jackson, Mobile, and on his return, at Richmond.
The usual amount of twaddle was indulged in by the Abolition press, deceiving the people now, as they have in the past, about the desperate straits of the Confederacy, "the visit of Jeff, Davis to restore their drooping courage, " and more of the same sort.
The New York Times, however, an Abolition paper, which is generally pretty candid, unless engaged in a political campaign, with shrewd foresight, and a cutting rebuke at our own Administration denominated his speeches as "crushingly truthful."

Subsequent events have proved that they were indeed "crushingly truthful." His last message beats the imprint of his analytical mind.
He commences with noticing enormous preparations of the United States as being so menacing as to excite grave apprehensions in the minds of many, but that the weight of numbers did not succeed.
There is no braggadocio about it. He mentions plainly the decisive repulses at Fredericksburg and Vicksburg and thus refers to the campaign in the West: "Obstinate battles have been fought with varied fortunes, marked by frightful carnage on both sides, but the enemy's hopes of decisive results have again been baffled." He thus refers to the prostitution of the war from its original purpose: "The war, which, in its inception, was waged for forcing us back into the Union, having failed to accomplish that purpose, passed into a second stage, in which it was attempted to conquer and rule these States as independent provinces.
Defeated in this second design, our enemies have evidently entered upon another, which can have no other purpose than revenge, and thirst for blood and plunder of private property."

This is absolutely true, and it cannot escape history any mere than Mr. Lincoln himself can. He then argues with his usual clearness and precision the various questions of public policy now agitating the world.

list.item:
III.
The rights of neutrals on the seas.

IV.
The Illegality of paper blockades and privateering.

VI.
The barbarities of the Federal Generals.

IX.
The operations of the War and Navy Departments.

div4.p:
All these questions Mr. Davis handles with consummate skill.
In treating of the rights of neutrals on the high seas he exposes with a trenchant blade the national sore of England — her perfidy.--We have no space now to dwell upon this, our main object being to call attention to the following paragraph, and ask that careful attention to it which his known truthfulness warrants:

q.p:
'To the unity and self-sacrificing patriotism hitherto displayed is due the success which has marked the unequal contest, and his brought our country into a condition at the present time such as the most sanguine would not have ventured to prodict at the commencement of the struggle.
Our armies are larger batter disciplined, and more thoroughly armed and equipped than at any period of the war; the energies of the whole nation, devoted to the single object of success in this war, have accomplished marvels, and many of our trials have, by a beneficent Providence, been converted into blessings. * * * * The injuries resulting from the intervention of foreign commerce have received compensation by the development of our internal resources Cannon crown our fortresses that were cast from the proceeds of mines opened and furness built during the war. Our mountain caves yield much of the ultre for the manufacture of powder, and promise of increased product.
From our own foundries and increased laboratories, from our own armories and workshops, we derive in a great measure the warlike material, the ordnance stores which are expended so profusely in the numerous and desperate engagements that rapidly succeed each other.
Cotton and woolen fabrics, shoes and harness, wagon and gun carriages, are produced in daily increasing quantities by the factories springing up into existence.
Our fields, no longer devoted to cotton that cannot be exported, are devoted to the products of cereals and the growth of stock, formerly purchased with the proceeds of cotton.
In the houses of our noble and devoted women — without whose sublime sacrifices our success would have been impossible — the noise of the loom and the spinning wheel may be heard throughout the land."

div4.p:
This is a plain, unvarnished tale, and no doubt strictly true, although it will not be palpable to those who have been deceiving the people by false predictions about the approaching end of the rebellion.
Future events will prove, as the past already shows, that the present Administration is incapable of preserving honesty in the Cabinet or winning victory in the field.
Of the emancipation proclamation he thus truthfully speaks:

"In its political aspect this measure possesses great significance, and to it, in this light, I invite your attention.
It affords to our whole people the complete and crowning proof of the true nature of the designs of the party which elevated to power the present occupant of the Presidential chair at Washington, and which ought to conceal its purpose by every variety of artful device and by the perfidious use of the most solemn and repeated pledges on every possible occasion.-- * * * * * * The people of the Confederacy, then, cannot fall to receive this proclamation as the fallest vindication of their own sagacity in foreseeing the uses to which the dominant party in the United States intended from the beginning to apply their power; nor can they cease to remember with devout thankfulness that it is to their own vigilance in resisting the first stealthy progress of approaching despotism that they owe their escape from consequences now apparent to the most skeptical." * * * It is also in effect an intimation to the people of the North that they prepare to to on now people are too sense not to understand that a resolution of the Union has been rendered forever impossible by the adoption of a measure which from its very nature, neither admits of retraction nor can co-exist with them. * * * * Humanity shudders at the appaling atrocities which are being daily multiplied under the sanction of those who have claimed temporary possession of the power to the United States, and who are fast making its once fair name a by word and reproach among civilized men. Not even the natural indignation inspired by his conduct should make us, however, so unjust as to attribute to the whole mass of the people who are subjected to the despotism that now reigns with unbridled license in the city of Washington, a willing acquiescence in its conduct of the war. There must necessarily exist among our enemies very many perhaps a majority, whose humanity recoils from all participation in such atrocities, but who cannot be held wholly guiltless while permitting their continuance without an effort at repression."

None of the great benefits predicted from the Emancipation Proclamation have been realized — The slaves have not risen and cut their masters' throats as the abolitionists so fondly hoped.
The effort of the slaves to free themselves was to have weakened the Confederate armies to such an extent as to make victory certain.
Well, the slaves have not risen, but it has been through the providence of God and not from the desire of Mr. Lincoln to the contrary.
He issued his incendiary address to them, inviting them to strike for freedom, but they have remained faithfully with their masters except where they have been driven away at the point of the bayonet by Federal troops.

Another grand effect of this great panacea for the Union was to frighten the South, and make them quake in their knees.
This food anticipation has not been realized.
Many unprotected women and children may quake upon retiring for the night, while their protectors are absent in the army, but they must put their trust in God and their faithful house-servants to protect them.
The President has just as much right to declare the marriage tie dissolved in the South as the bond of master and servant.
One is as much a military necessity as the other.
Who but a madman or fool believes that the Union can be restored by such means?

div4.head: The particulars of the arrest.
div4.p: The editorial given appeared on Tuesday morning, and the particulars of the arrest are thus detailed in the presentment of the Grand Jury:

On Tuesday night, Jan. 27, 1863, between 11 and 12 o'clock. Albert D. Boileau, a citizen of this Commonwealth and a resident of this city, upon returning to his home was taken into custody by military officers in the service of the United States and taken away from this city and conveyed to Fort McHenry, a military fortress of the United States, near Baltimore, in the State of Maryland.
That said officers acted under and in pursuance of a special order issued by Gen. Schenck, the commanding General of the Eight Army Corps, in which department this city is, to Gen. Montgomery, commanding at Philadelphia, which order is as follows:

div5.head:
Headq'rs 8th Army Corps,
Baltimore, Md., Jan. 14, 1863.
div5.p: Special Orders No. 24--Brigadier General Montgomery will immediately arrest and send under a sufficient guard to Fort McHenry, Baltimore, Albert D. Boileau, the publisher and editor of the Philadelphia Evening Journal, for the publication of an editorial article under the title of "Davis's Message," in his paper of January 20, 1863, and for the publication of other articles of like dangerous character tending to the support and encouragement of rebellion against the Government of the United States.
He will also take measures to suppress the publication of the Philadelphia Evening Journal, the paper in question, until further orders.
div5.closer:
By command of Maj. Gen. Schenck.
Wm. D. Whipple, A. A. Gen.
To Brig. Gen. Montgomery.

div5.p: That Gen. Montgomery, in pursuance of said order, and in the execution thereof, issued an order to the Provost Marshal of the city directing and requesting him to arrest and convey the said Boileau to Fort McHenry.
That the officers that immediately made said arrest and executed said order were Howard Livingston, aid to Gen. Montgomery, and Lieut. Michael Coster, Lieutenant of the Provost Guard.

And the grand inquest further present that the cause of said arrest and removal of said Boileau, as assigned in said special order, was the publication of an editorial under the title of "Davis's Message," in his paper of January 20, 1863, and for the publication of other articles of like dangerous character tending to the support and encouragement of the rebellion against the Government of the United States.

The grand inquest further present as a fact connected with the said arrest, that one Edward Carr, a citizen of this Commonwealth, and residing in this city, who witnessed the arrest of said Boileau, was then and there taken into custody, and conveyed to the guard house of the provost guard, and there detained until the next morning, when he was discharged; that said arrest of said Carr was made by direction of said military officers solely to prevent said Carr from taking any measures that might interfere with the execution of the said order for the arrest and removal of said Boileau.--The grand jury have thus stated simply the facts they were desired to by the Court when this matter was given them in charge.
Yet they cannot refrain from saying that they, whilst indirectly or as a body could not conscientiously do anything which would have a tendency to weaken the arm of the General Government in the exercise of its constitutional authority for the suppression of this most wicked and causeless rebellion, yet they feel equally b to enforce all the laws that have the protection of life, the security of property, and the liberty of the citizens in their sacred keeping.
After reading the presentment Judge Ludlow said:

q.p:
"I have read the special presentment just handed to me by the foreman.
As it contains a detailed statement of the facts connected with the late military arrest, together with the names of the persons who have made that arrest, and as it also contains your opinion, as well concerning the wickedness of the rebellion as the method which the Government has adopted to suppress it, it will be filed.
I shall then request the District Attorney to examine the document, and to frame such bills of indictment as he may find to be necessary, in support not only of the laws of the State of Pennsylvania, but of the Constitution of the United States.
We can then arrive at the question of the legality of the charges therein contained.
The record will then present the detailed charges, and the defendants may object to the prosecution for any cause they may have, and they may also have the judgment of this Court, and also the final judgment of the Supreme Court, in case they should be dissatisfied with the finding of this Court."

div5.p: The Grand Jury was then discharged.

div4.head: The excitement in Philadelphia — meeting of the Democratic Association.
div4.p:
The correspondent of the World says that "public excitement and indignation" in Philadelphia was higher than at any time before, and the "more conservative Democrats" feared that the despotic and lawless acts of the Federal authorities would lead to bloodshed.
He adds:

q.p:
It was proposed that we should hold a mass meeting, to give formal and forcible, expression to public sentiment and feeling; but leading Democrats discouraged it, lest it might lead to a riot.
They say that such a multitude of enraged people as a call would assemble in Independence Square, after listening to the indignant speeches that would be made, however the speakers might counsel order and a reliance upon law for redress and protection, would be likely to sally forth and destroy the offices of the Abolition newspapers, which would lead to a collision with the military, to bloodshed, and parhaps to scenes such as Paris saw in the bloody days of France.
Therefore it has been decided to call no mass meeting at present, but to await the result of legislation and other State action in the premises; to wait and see whether or not the Federal authorities will release Mr. Boileau and permit the publication of his journal without condition or restraint beyond what the laws of the land impose upon him. If he be not released I fear for the result.
Hundreds of its late most respectable supporters here now repudiate the Administration as a disgrace and an outrage upon the American people.
It would seem that the Federal authorities are making a special effort to provoke the scorn and indignation of the civilized world, and to bring about the destruction of everything dear to the American people, by provoking a civil war in the North as well as in the South.

div4.p:
The lately organized Democratic Club, of this city, had an exciting and highly interesting meeting last evening.
Charles Ingersoll presided — Speeches were made by Hon. Wm. H. White, Geo. M. Wharton, Peter McCall, George W. Biddle, and John C. Bullitt, Esqs., of this city, and by Hon. Wm. H. Miller, member elect of Congress from the Harrisburg district.
A more respectable meeting as to the talent, moral character, social position, and genuine patriotism of those in at attendance, has never assembled in this city since the session of the Constitutional Convention and the National Congress were held here.
The speech of Mr. White was bitter in its condemnation of the late outrageous act of the Federal power.
He denounced it as an outrage upon rights and privileges acquired by the blood of the Revolution — rights which were secured to us before the Federal Government was organized, and which, when it was formed, were not surrendered, but reserved to the States respectively, and to the people thereof, as indefensible, indestinatible rights, and as independent of the Federal power, especially of the military power, as of the Government of Great Britain or Russia.
He said he had understood that resolutions had been offered in the Legislature calling upon the Governor to protect against this insult to the sovereign dignity of the State of Pennsylvania.
If he had been a member of that body he would have introduced articles of impeachment against a man who, having been choice by the people of the State to represent its sovereignty and to execute its laws, had permitted similar outrages to be committed under his very nose without his protect or objection.
He considered that Gov. Curtin had been a spectator of unpardonable outrages upon the honor and dignity of his State and people, which he is sworn and bound in honor to protect, and therefore he ought to be impeached.
This sentiment was received with a perfect of applause.

Mr. Wharton followed in a calm, temperate and able speech, in which he said that he had hoped that this business of arbitrary arrest was about to be — if it had not already been — abandoned, but this arrest of Mr. Boileau was a startling proof that he was mistaken.
He then proceeded to speak of its unlawfulness and to denounce it in such terms as became a Christian gentleman and patriot.

Mr. McCall made a stirring speech in the course of which he expressed the fear that the lawless course of the Administration would provoke lawlessness on the part of the people.
If they could not be protected under and by the law, it was natural that they should seek redress outside the law; but he hoped that the friends of law and order would be able to prevent any violence.

Mr. Biddle followed in a similar strain, and said that the Journal was too good, too candid, and too able a paper to please the Administration; that it had exposed the wickedness of the Federal authorities so searchingly and truthfully as to provoke the fears of the Administration.
Hence its suppression and the imprisonment of its publisher and proprietor.
Mr. B. denounced these acts of the Administration in just though severe terms.

Mr. Bullitt made a most exciting and telling speech.
He said that he had noticed what efforts had been made by the gentlemen who had preceded him to choke down their indignation in order that they might spark soberly and calmly upon the exciting topic of the hour; their hearts were ready to burst with pent up emotions of anger and disgust, yet they had managed to speak as became conservators of the public peace and good order--Mr. Bullitt said that the Administration was trampling upon the rights and privileges which have been acquired by the blood and struggles of two centuries--which belonged to the American people even before the formation of the Constitution.
He said there was a point beyond which human endurance could not be expected to extend.
That our people had endured much — they had given their money and their relatives and friends to be sacrificed — they had seen their most sacred rights trampled upon, and their peaceable fellow-citizens outraged, and it seemed they were called upon to endure more; but he warned all concerned that this could not be much longer.
He asked who would desire to preserve his life if he must live without liberty?. He thought an act like this arrest of Mr. Boileau.
If committed in New York, would lead to civil war in the North.
Here some one-said (according to a flying rumor) that the editor of the New York World had been arrested "Then," said Mr. Bullitt, "that act inaugurates a revolution in the North! [At this point the excitement was most intense, and the applause was terrific, and continued several minutes.
Mr. Bullitt, though in favor of law and order, so long as they were assured to us advised the conservative men of Philadelphia to prepare for the worst, (when there was another storm of applause and shouts of approval) I cannot pretend, from memory, to give a just outline of Mr. B.'s speech, nor, indeed, of any of the speeches; but you may be assured that it stirred the hitherto sluggish blood of his auditors and reawakened their long slumbering manhood.
It recalled the scense that Wirt has painted in Patrick Henry's career.
I report these things in simple fidelity, for the Administration at Washington should know that Mr. B.'s speech is the key-note of public feeling in Philadelphia, and should be heeded as a warning of a terrible "wrath to come," if these infamous outrages are continued.
The fire that has long been smothered beneath a wet blanket has well nigh dried its covering, and is liable to break forth in a blaze at any moment "Give us liberty, or give us death." may, ere long, be set in white letters on red flags, borne by men wrought up to desperation by their base betrayers in office. "One extreme begets another"--especially the extreme of tyranny, the parent of anarchy.

The speech of Gen. Miller, of Harrisburg, was very gold, and was well received.
He said he had been for the war before Congress had shown that it was insincere when it passed the Crittenden resolution.
He now considered it evident that the war had been perverted from its original (professed) purpose, and changed to a negro war. Gen. M.'s strictures upon the Administration were sharp as they were just.
He animadverted upon the arrest of Mr. Boileau in fitting terms, and resumed his seat amid cries of "go on." and applause.

It is now known that Mr. Boileau is incarcerated in Fort McHenry, where he is "doing as well as could be expected" He is reported as being in good spirits, considering the circumstances.
I predict that he will not yield a principle of right, or succumb in the least degree to his infamous and cowardly oppressors.

Unfortunately for the prediction of the correspondent, Mr. Boileau did "yield a principle of right," and did "succumb" by procuring his release through an apology for and retraction of the article for which he was incarcerated.
He, however, was but a single frightened individual — the people who resented the outrage upon him neither yielded nor succumbed.

div3.head: Committal of Major Reid Sanders to Fort Lafayette.
div3.p:
--Major Reid Sanders, who fell into the hands of the blockaders off Charleston with the "intercepted dispatches," was examined in New York on the 1st inst., and committed to Fort Lafayette.
The Herald says:

q.p:
He was then under the assumed name of George A. Sherman, and claimed to be a British subject — He was dressed in mechanics' apparel and on being searched documents were found secreted on his person which confirmed the suspicion that he was bearer of rebel dispatches.
Sanders was conveyed to this port, and transmitted from the Navy Yard, Brooklyn, to the custody of the United States Marshal, where it was thought he would be a valuable witness in condemning the prize vessel on board of which he was when captured.
He here denied his identity, insisted that his name was Shermen, and that he was a British subject.
This subterfuge was, however, detected by Prize Commissioner Elliott, who recognized him as Reid Sanders, son of George Sanders, with whom he (the Commissioner) had been well acquainted.

div3.p:
The Marshal said he was also, acquainted with Sanders's father and mother, and that the movements of the accused were watched from the time he left home until he was brought to this city.--Sanders ultimately acknowledged his name, and admitted that he was known at home as Major Reid Sanders, of the Confederate army.
He asked that he might not be sent to Fort Lafayette, as he was in bad health.
A physician, however, was consulted, and he was transmitted to Fort Lafayette on Saturday, under the charge of Deputies Peel and Buckley.
Major Reid Sanders is some what like his father, stout and stunted, ruddy complexion, and about twenty five years of age.--His apparel was an excellent disguise, and completely, transformed the man of military bearing into the laborer in scarch of hire.

div3.head: Napoleon's views with Regard to Mexico.
div3.p:
The assertion of Napoleon regarding Mexico, as contained in his letter to Gen. Forey, the French commander in that country, is important.
The following is an extract of the letter:

q.p:
There will not be wanting people who will ask you why we go to lavish men and money for the establishment of a regular Government in Mexico.
In the present state of the civilization of the world the prosperity of America is not a matter of indifference to Europe; for it is she who feeds our manufactories and gives life to our commerce.
We have an interest in this — that the Republic of the United States be powerful and prosperous, but we have none in this — that she should seize possession of all the Mexican Gulf, dominate from thence the Antilles, as well as South America, and be the sole dispenser of the products of the New World.
We see now, by sad experience, how precarious is the fate of an industry which is reduced to seeking its chief raw material in one market alone, to all the vicissitudes of which it has to submit.
If, on the other hand, Mexico preserves its influence and maintains the integrity of its territory, if a stable Government is constituted with the assistance of France, we shall have restored to the Latin race on the other side of the ocean its strength and prestige; we shall have established our beneficent influence in the centre of America, and this influence, by presenting immense opening for our commerce, will procure us the materials indispensable to our industry.
Mexico thus regenerated will always be favorable to us, not only from gratitude, but also because her interests will be in harmony with ours, and she will find a powerful support in her good relations with the European Powers.
To-day then, our pledged military honor, the exigency of our policy, the interest of our industry and of our commerce, all make it a duty to march upon Mexico, and boldly plant there our flag, to establish either a monarchy, if it is not incompatible with the national sentiments of the country, or at all events a Government which promises some stability.

div3.head: The reported destruction of the Florida.
div3.p: --The Northern papers, of the 2d, contain the rumors which were in circulation at Havana on the 28th ult, of the loss of the Confederate steamer Florida, (use Oyieto.). The following is a summary of the rumors:

q.p:
On Tuesday, January 27, it was reported in Havana that heavy firing had been heard at Matanas and Cardenas, as if coming from vessels of war engaged in a serious contest at sea. It was also stated that the Florida or some other rebel vessel had been chased by several Union gunboats; but with what result had not been learned.
It was then believed at Matanzas that the firing and chasing were connected with the same vessel.
This rumor was strengthened by the arrival of the Croole, from New York, on the following day, which reported that she had been spoken by the Union gunboat Cayuga, which vessel reported that she had observed a steamer on fire, supposed to be the Florida, and that three other vessels were firing into her with great rapidity.
The locality of this engagement was not definitely stated; but that it was in the vicinity of the Cayes, off Cardenas and Matanass.

div3.head: Charleston.
div3.p:
--The Northern papers say that all the officers' wives at Port Royal have been ordered North in view of active operations from that point against Charleston.
The British frigate Cadmus visited Charleston Tuesday to notify Robert Bunch, H. B. M. Consul there, that a naval attack would soon be made on that city, and to take him to Havana.
Mr. B. leaves there to- morrow.
The iron clad Ironsides and thirteen blockading steamers are still lying off Charleston.

div4.p: --The Senate met at 12 o'clock M. and was called to order by Mr. Hunter, of Va., and was opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. Hallack
Mr. Johnson, of Ga., introduced a bill to the impressment of privates property for public use, which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
Mr. Johnson also presented a bill to repeal the act of Congress of the United States, approved March 2d, 1838, commonly known as the force bill, which was referred to the Judiciary Committee.

Mr. Johnson also introduced "a bill to propose an amendment to the Constitution of the Confederate States, viz: 1.
It is enacted by the Congress of the Confederate States, two-thirds of both Houses thereof concurring, that the following amendment to the Constitution of the Confederate States of America be, and the same is hereby proposed and when ratified by the Legislatures of three fourths of the several States shall be a part of said Constitution, and shall be inserted therein as clause 2d, 1st of Art. V., to with "When any State being aggrieved by any sat of Congress, shall by Convention declare the cause to be unconstitutional, Congress, if in session, and if not, the President, shall convene it for that purpose — shall immediately call a Convention of the States to consider said act, and, if not, if not affirmed by two-thirds of said.
Convention, the vote to be taken by States, it shall be void and no law, but if affirmed it shall stand; and it affirmed, and no adjustment can be made by amendment or otherwise satisfactory to the complaining State, and it determine to secede from the Confederacy, it shall do so in peace, but shall be entitled to its pro rata share of the public debt, to be determined and settled by negotiation.
2. That the President shall transmit to the Governor of each State a copy of the act to be submitted by him to the Legislature thereof for ratification.

The Senate resumed the consideration of the bill to organize the Supreme Court of the Confederate States. Mr. Phelan of Miss, again addressed the Senate in exposition of his views.
He stated the pending question to be. "Has Congress the power to grant to the Supreme Courts, appeallate jurisdiction over the State Courts, in cases arising under she Constitution and the laws of the Confederate States.?
On conclusion of Mr. Phelan's remarks, Mr. Johnston, of Ga. obtained the floor.

The Military Committee reported a substitute for the bill granting transportation home and backwards to soldiers, extending the privilege to all soldiers who have enlisted for the war; also a bill withholding all furloughs from soldiers until after the 1st of July next.
The Senate than went into Executive session, and on the opening of the doors adjourned.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock, and was opened with prayer by Rev. Mr. Crumley.
Hon. Mr. Simpson, of S. C., elected to supply the vacancy in the delegation from that State, occasioned by the resignation of Gen. Bonham, qualified and took his seat.

Resolutions Reported and Referred.--By Mr. Slugleton, of Miss: A resolution that the Judiciary Committee be instructed to inquire into the following propositions, viz: 1st, the expediency of a recommendation by Congress to the several States of the Confederacy, that they prohibit by law foreignborn persons (not naturalized) from holding real estate within their respective borders; 2d the constitutionality and expediency of an act of Congress requiring every fore ga-born person, not naturalized before he shall engage in trade or commerce within the Confederate States, to obtain license for that purpose, upon paying into the Treasury of the Confederacy a sum to be specified by law; and that he be further required to render, from time to time, an account, under oath, of the not proceeds arising from such trade or commerce, upon which he shall be taxed a certain per cent.

By Mr. Smith, of North Carolina: A resolution that the President be requested to communicate to the House the number and amount of claims for vessels seized by order of the naval and military authorities for the public use, filed in the War and Navy Departments, the names of the claimants, the time when severally filed, and the estimated sums required for their payment.
Agreed to.

Also, a resolution of inquiry into the expediency of providing by law for the auditing and payment of claims for cotton and other property destroyed by the military authorities of the Confederate Government, or by the owners to prevent the same from falling into the hands of the enemy.
Agreed to.

Also, a resolution that the same committee be instructed to report a bill providing for the payment of the amount due the State of North Carolina for clothing furnished the troops of the State, according to the account No. 253, as audited in the Second Auditor's office.
Agreed to.

Also, a resolution that the Judiciary Committee be directed to inquire whether the organized forces of an invading army, captured in the act of carrying out the declared policy of their Government, can be held amenable, in consonance with the principles of public law and the usage of nations, to the criminal laws of the invaded country, and be dealt with as felons by its civil tribunals; and if not what legislation is required to enable the Confederate States, by means of reprisals and retaliation, to repress the atrocities of an instigated insurrection.
Agreed to.

Also, a resolution that the Committee of Ways and Means be directed to consider the expediency of raising a revenue to support the Government and pay the interest on the public debt to be derived by assessment upon the following subjects of taxation, to wit: 1.
The product of the farm, forest, and sea, and the increase in value of stock not required for the use and consumption of the producer or owner.
2d.
The net proceeds from investments of money and other capital in manufacturing, mining, mechanical, and other industrial operations carried on by associated capital or hired labor.
3d.
The dividends and profits earned by railroad, banking, and other private companies, to be paid by the corporations.
4th.
Money at interest, except when invested in State securities.
5th.
Salaries and fees of all officers, State and Confederate, except such as are paid out of the Treasury of the several States, except non commissioned officers and privates--6th.
The profits of speculation, and the enhanced value of all property bought for re Agreed to.

By Mr. Bridges, of N. C.: A resolution that the Committee of Ways and Means be instructed to inquire into the expediency of taxing the incomes of speculators, extortioners, and others receiving large profits.
Agreed to.

By Mr. Ayer, of S. C: A resolution that it be referred to the Committee of Ways and Means to inquire and report, by bill or otherwise, on the expediency of levying an export duty on tobacco and naval stores, similiar to the export duty levied on cotton for the purpose of paying the war debt of the Confederate States.
Agreed to.

By Mr. Miles, of S. C: A resolution that the Committee on Commerce be instructed to inquire into the expediency of framing such legislation for the regulation of navigation and the coasting trade as may be it subserve the true interests of the Confederate States upon the re- establishment of unrestricted commercial intercours; with foreign nations.
Agreed to.

Also, a resolution that the Committee on Foreign Affairs be instructed to-inquire into the expediency of regulating by law the subject of naturalization of foreigners, with a view to such a discrimination against persons not now citizens of the Confederate States, as may best tend to promote the stability and purity of our political and social institutions.
Agreed to.

Also, a resolution that the Committee on Military Affairs be instructed to inquire into the expediency of providing compensation by law to the owners of slaves escaping to or captured by the enemy, when such slaves are in the employment of the Confederate Government, and engaged on works of military defence.
Agreed to.

By Mr. Farrow, of S. C: A resolution that the Committee of Ways and Means be instructed to inquire and report on the expediency of putting in operation the Mint at Charlotte, in the State of North Carolina.
Agreed to.

By Mr. Foote, of Tenn: A resolution that the Judiciary Committee be instructed to inquire whether it is not inexpedient to attempt the execution of the retaliatory policy upon the forces of the enemy found upon Southern soil, armed for the execution of the late incendiary proclamation of President Lincoln.
Agreed to.

Also, a resolution that the Committee of Ways and Means be instructed to inquire into the expediency of providing by some general act for the indemnification of those citizens who have been subjected to pecuniary loss by the destruction of cotton, tobacco, and other agricultural products, by the act of our own Government, in order to keep the same out of the hands of the enemy.--Agreed to.

Also, a resolution that a special committee of five be instructed to inquire particularly into the existing condition of the transportation service on the line of railroad extending from Vicksburg, Miss., to Mobile, Ala., and report to this House the facts of the cash, in order that the proper remedy herein may be promptly applied; also, to inquire into the same subject in reference to the line of the Mobile and Ohio Railroad, from Meridian to Cholous, in the State of Mississippi, and also, the line of railroads from Richmond to Charleston, S. C. Agreed to.

By Mr. Heiskell, of Tenn: A resolution that the Committee on Military Affairs be requested to inquire and report what steps have been taken by the War Department for awarding medals to the soldiers who have distinguished themselves in battle that they further he instructed to report what legislation is proper (in case difficulties exist in the preparation of medals) to provide certificates of title upon which the same can be claimed when prepared.
Agreed to.

By Mr. Bottler.
of Va: A resolution that the Committee on Military Affairs inquire into the expediency of re-organizing the army by consolidating reduced regiments, &c. Agreed to.

Also, a resolution that all bills on the subject of making Treasury notes a legal tender, which were on the calendar at-the-end of the last session be referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, Agreed to.

By Mr. Baldwin, of Va: A resolution that the Committee on Post-Offices and Post Roads inquire into the expediency of reducing the expenses of the Post-Office. Department within its means by abolishing the department; and if it is inexpedient to abolish the department, to inquire into the expediency of allowing express companies to carry matter with postage pre-paid.
The two prepositions embraced in the resolution were voted upon separately, and the first was lost and the second laid on the table.

By Mr. Holcombe, of Va: A resolution that the Committee on Printing be instructed to inquire into the expediency of amending ajoint resolution entitled "resolution for the preservation of public documents, approved April 19th, 1862. "

By Mr. Lyons, of Va.: A resolution that the President be requested to inform this House whether private property not of citizens not in the army has been seized and confiscated by his order, or not, and if it has been, for what offence, and under what law such seizure and confiscation has been ordered.
Agreed to.

By Mr. Beldwiz: A resolution that the President be requested to communicate to this House a list of all civilliant now in custody under authority of the War Department, giving his name, residence and occupation, with the date of his arrest, the offence charged against him, and the place of his imprisonment.
Agreed to.

Also, a resolution that the Committee on Quartermaster and Commissary Departments inquire into the expediency; 1st of discontinuing the allowances of commutation for quarters and feel to officers at posts or hospitals, or making some equivalent allowance to officers in the field; 2d, of limiting the number of horses to be kept by officers at posts or hospitals to such as may be allowed to each officer, for the duties of his position, by special order of the commander of the department; 3d.
of limiting the right of purchasing supplies for the quartermaster and commissary departments to officers serving in the field, and for their personal use while so serving 4th, of allowing to Chaplains in the field one ration, and forage for one horse.
Agreed to.

Joint Resolutions.--By Mr. Miles, of S. C., a joint resolution of thanks to Capt. Duncan N. Ingraham, and the officers and men of his command for their successful attack upon the blockading fleet of the enemy off the harbor of Charleston by which the fleet was partially destroyed and entirely dispersed.

Also, a joint resolution of thanks to Lieut.- Col. Yates, and the officers and men of his command for their gallant and successful attack upon and capture of the enemy's gunboat, J. P. Smith, in the Stono river near Charleston, S. C.
These resolutions were appropriately referred.

Bills Reported and Referred.--By Mr. Smith, of N. C., a bill to establish a bureau in connection with the War Department to be known at the Bureau of Transportation.
Referred to Committee on Quartermaster and Commissary Departments.

By Mr. Vest, of Mo., a bill to provide for the payment of officers acting under temporary appointment from the commander of any department, corps division or brigade.
Referred to Military Committee.

By the same, a bill for the relief of certain officers and soldiers from the State of Missouri.
Referred to same committee.

By Mr. Boteler, of Va. a bill to provide for the appointment of Military Storekeepers in the Provisional Army of the Confederate States.
Referred to the ordnance Committee.
By Mr. Russal, of Va: A bill to restrict the issue of Treasury notes and to substitute certificates of loan to a certain amount:

The Congress of the Confederate States do enact, That until the first day of July next no more Treasury notes (not bearing interest) shall be issued from the Treasury during any week than shall have been redeemed or invested in bonds of the Confederate States or in interest-bearing.
Treasury notes during the proceeding week.

2. In any payments lawfully to be made before the 1st day of July next the President may cause to be issued and paid out certificates of loan for the sums of ten dollars and any multiples thereof, respectively, promising to the bearer that the same shall be convertible into bonds of the Confederate States bearing interest at the rate of seven per cent. per annum, if such certificates be presented for conversion in sums of one hundred dollars or any multiple thereof within three months after the expiration of the month in which such certificates shall respectively bear date, but not more than one hundred millions of dollars of such certificates shall be issued.
The President may cause the necessary bonds to be made and issued for the redemption or conversion of such certificates, which bonds, bearing interest as aforesaid, payable semi-annually, shall be redeemable at the option of the Government, not less than five nor more than thirty years after the date thereof.

3. Such certificates shall be in such form and signed in such manner as the President shall prescribe.
Referred to the Committee of Ways and Means.
The House then went into secret session.

--The Senate met at 12 o'clock M. and was called to order by the Lieut.-Governor.
Prayer by Rev. Dr. J. C. McCabe.

House bill to relieve the Society of Dunkards from payment of the fines due the State for non- military duty, the Confederate Government having enacted a similar law, was taken up and unanimously passed.

Resolution of Inquiry.--By Mr. Whittle: That the Governor inform the Senate of the number of arms of all kinds which have been handed over to the Confederate Government by the State of Virginia, and on what terms; and the terms on which the State repairs arms, etc; and whether any arms passed by the State have been returned to it by the Confederacy, etc.

A bill to limit the production of tobacco and increase that of grain, after having been thoroughly debated, discussed, sifted, and amended, was put upon its passage, and the yeas and nays being ended thereon resulted as follows: Yeas 18, nays 22.--So the bill was defeated.
And then, on motion of Mr. Johnson, at twenty minutes to 3 P. M. the Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of Delegates.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock M. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Reid.

The report of the committee of conference on the disagreement of the two House relative to the discharge from military service of such persons as have furnished substitutes for three years, or the war, was, on motion of Mr. Bucks, with the consent of the Senate re-committed to the committee for amendment.

A bill was reported regulating the mode and manner of binding out free negroes as apprentices.
Ordered to its second reading.

Resolutions of Inquiry.--The following resolutions of inquiry were submitted: By Mr. Nelson; Into the expediency of providing by law for the exemption of one deputy clerk for each county;--agreed to. By Mr. Carpenter; Into the expediency or repealing an act passed Oct. 3, 1862, relative to public defence.
By Mr. Baskerville: Into the expediency of establishing a State Military Hospital at Randolph Macon College.
By Mr. Forbes: That the Committee of Courts inquire into the expediency of providing by law that when any deed of trust, or other writing heretofore executed for the conveyance of land or other property in this State, an advertisement is required in any locality held by the public enemy such advertisement shall be made in some newspaper in Richmond city, with the same valid effect as if published in the locality mentioned in the deed of writing.
By Mr. Fleming: Instructing the Committee on Salt to correspond with the proprietors of the Washington and Smythe county Salt Works, with reference to a renewal of county contracts when the present contracts shall have ceased.--agreed to.

The hour of 12½ having arrived, the consideration of the extortion bill was resumed.
At the adjournment on yesterday the House was discussing the motion of Mr. Hunter, to strike out the tenth section.
The first business of the morning hour, therefore, was upon that subject--Mr. Anderson, of Botetout, obtaining the floor in opposition to the motion.

Amendments, substitutes and speeches were freely indulged in until three o'clock, when the bill and its amendments, together with a substitute offered by Mr. Anderson, of Rockbridge, were laid upon the table and ordered to be printed.
On motion of Mr. Bouldin, the report of the committee of conference on the substitute bill was taken up — it having been previously reported back to the House, and agreed to.
On motion, the House adjourned.

[During the discussion of a pending question, Major-General Sterilog Price appeared in the hall, whereupon Mr. Robinson, of Richmond city, offered a resolution — which was unanimously agreed to — tendering him a seat upon the floor of the House.
Gen. P. was introduced to the Speaker by Mr. Anderson, of Botstourt, and in announcing the decision of the House, Speaker Shefley said:

q.p: "Gen. Price, it is with pleasure that I communicate to you the resolution just adopted by the House of Delegated, tendering you a privileged seat in this body during your stay in this city — a testimonial due your gallant services to your country — service which will ever be embalmed in a nation's gratitude."

div4.p: General Prior replied:

q.p: "Mr. Speaker, allow me to say that I feel grateful to the Legislature of my native State for the honor they have conferred upon me. 0022;

div4.p: The General remained in the House up to the hour of adjournment, receiving the congratulations of members generally.

div3.head: Confederate bonds are now selling at 100½
div3.p: --The city of Petersburg on Wednesday invested $90,000 in them.
Fighting Jos. Hooker was at a party at Secretary Chase's on the night of the 1st inst.
Paul Murphy, the chess player, is in Paris, but not playing match games.
Gen. McClellan had been invited to visit Portland Mo.

div3.head: Latest from the North.
div3.p: --Northern papers of the 31 have been received here.

At St. Louis great sympathy was manifested for the Confederate prisoners taken at Arkansas Post, who passed through that city.
One of the prisoners was allowed to make a speech.
The Federal papers pronounce the affair "an ovation to treason."
Van-Dorn is reported to be advancing on Memphis.
The Yankees say there are 50,000 Confederates at Holly Springs, Miss.
McClellan was received with great enthusiasm at Boston.
Napoleon says that the United States must not possess Mexico and control the products of the New World.

Reports from North Carolina say there is an immense force near Beaufort waiting for good weather to attack.
(Charleston)

The bill enlisting negro soldiers has passed the House of Representatives by a vote of 38 to 51 --The slaves of loyal persons will not be received, and no recruiting officer under the bill will be opened in the border States without permission from the State Governors.

In the debate on the bill Thaddeus Stevens of Pennsylvania, said that 300,000 men would leave the army in May, and the North could not raise 50,000 while men to take their places.
He also stated that he believed the Democrats were holding secret meetings to usurp the Presidency.
From Rosecrans's army an engagement is reported on the 26th, at Woodbury, in which the Confederates fled, losing their commander and 34 others.
Franklin, Tenn., is in the hands of the Federals.
The arrest of deserters from the Federal army to being resisted in Indiana. The cavalry engaged the service were fired on by the mob.
Gov. Morgan has been nominated by the Abolition caucus for candidate for the New York Senatorship.
Federal green backs have been decided by the courts in California not to be a legal tender.

The Oreto (Florida) is certainly destroyed.
It is reported from Havana that she was struck by a shell and sunk off Matanase.
Horace Vernet, the celebrated French painter, died recently in Paris.
Gold on Monday opened at 160 and close at 158½ Exchange 177.

div3.head: A Yankee Exaggeration.
div3.p:
--The "Cavalry raid" spoken of in recent Yankee papers as having been made on Chantilly, was merely a scouting party of a dozen men under Captain Mothy of Stuart's Cavalry, who, after having captured a Yankee picket, were pursued to Middleburg, when two of them were taken.
The remainder of the "twenty-four" claimed to have been captured did not belong to the scout, but were stragglers from other commands, and twelve of them deserters from the Yankee army.

div3.head: The Executions to-day.
div3.p:
--Three men are to expiate their offences to-day in or near this city by sudden and ignominious deaths.
Michael Buston, condemned at the last term of Judge Lyons's Court for the murder of John Delaney in December last, will suffer at the usual place of execution, below the Powder Magazine, between the hours of ten and two o'clock.--This execution will be conducted by the civil authorities, the Sergeant and his deputies officiating on the occasion.
James Broderick and Michael.
Kearns, members of the Letcher artillery, will suffer death by musketry, between the hours of 2 and 3 o'clock, at Camp Lee is presence of all their brother soldiers in the vicinity of the city, they having been condemned to death for the crime of desertion by the Court-Martial now in session here.
Kearne, one of the military prisoners was very much dejected last night, and seemed to have lost all hope.

div3.head: Important decision
div3.p:
--A few days since an important decision was rendered in the Richmond Circuit Court, Judge John A. Meredith presiding, to which the attention of our citizens having property on the high seas may very property be directed.
The decision was rendered in the case of Edmond, Davenport & Co. vs.
the Merchants' Insurance Company of this city.
This suit was brought upon a policy of insurance upon the bark Sallie Mages, which sailed from Rio. de Janeiro, laden with coffee for this port, in the spring of 1861, and was captured by Lincoln's ships of war off the Capes of Virginia in the month of July, 1861. The company refused to pay the insurance and the case, after having been elaborately argued before Judge Meredith, was decided by him in favor of the plaintiffs.

The points involved were both novel and interesting and embraced references to our past and present political, historical, and judicial career — especially in relation to the laws of war, blockade, belligerent rights, as affecting the contract, but principally as governing restraining, and explaining the sense and interpretation of the original Contract of insurance between the parties.
This was a test case and many others are dependent upon its final decision.
An appeal will be, it is presumed, applied for to the Supreme Court of Appeals of the State of Virginia.
Counsel for the plaintiffs, Messrs. Crump and Morson; for the defendants, Messrs. Grattan and Howard.

div3.head: An important case.
div3.p:
--The decision of the habeas corpus case of Theodore Whiteman before Judge Lyons, of the Richmond Hustings Court, is looked for with much interest, involving as it does the power of the President to declare and continue in force for more than a year martial law, and the trial of citizens before a court-martial for offences denounced by him in his proclamation.
The arguments in the case of Whitman, a citizen arrested for some offence, by the military authorities, and sought to be tried therefor before the Court-Martial, have been fully heard before Judge Lyons by Mr. Wm. W. Crump on behalf of the petitioner and Mr. Robert Ould on behalf of the Government.--Concluded several days since and now held under advisement, it will be decided on Saturday, when the mooted and important question whether the citizen is amenable to military law or act, will be fully decided.

div3.head: Prison Items.
div3.p:
--The following arrivals were chronicled yesterday at Castle thunder Patrick Gregory, arrested while making his way to the Yankees, as it is supposed, Richard L. Bohannon, of Rogere's cavalry, C. Drunwright, G. G. Marshall Partrick Kelley, James Travis, and John Casey, as substitutes and substitute agents, Wm. A. Joynes, substitute and deserter.
Noah Range, a prisoner sent from Abingdon, Va., died yesterday in the prison.
Thomas Martin, James T. Payun, Nelson Euroughly William Carr, William Fitzgerald, and William Boydton, soldiers, were discharged from the Castle yesterday and sent to their respective regiments.

div3.head: Substitute agent arrested.
div3.p:
--Messrs. Castle and Franklin, of the Provost Marshall Detective Police, arrested yesterday and committed to Castle Thunder a notorious personage named Wm. H. Murphy, formerly a Captain in the 1st La. regiment, and latterly a well known substitute agent.
He is held for trial before the Court-Martial now in session.

div3.head: West Point in the United States Senate.
div3.p:
In a late debate in the United States Senate, Lane of Kansas, Trumbull, and other radicals of that body, let loose the vials of their wrath upon.
West Point, which they endeavored to saddle with all the failure of their arms in this war. The Yankees have various ways of accounting for their want of success; but the attempt to saddle it upon West Point in the most irrational and absurd of all. If it had not been for West Point they would never have gained a single battle, no matter what their preponderance of numbers.
Destitute of all military aptitude, it is only the discipline which West Point has given them that has made their superior numerial strength in any degree formidable.
They could never have recovered from the shock of the first battle of Manassas but for the incessant training of a whole year, which West Point subjected them to before they could be trusted in another great battle.
Trumbull talks wildly of pushing right on and overwhelming the rebels, but never seems to take into account either the military obstacles or those of supplies and transportation which would have to be encountered.
One of the Senators pertinently suggested that if his Republican colleagues, who can describe so satisfactorily what ought to have been done, would themselves lead the armies instead of criticizing the leaders, it would be easier to determine between the comparative merits of educated and uneducated military men.--But this is no part of the programme of the Republican incendiaries in Congress or the Cabinet.
Their mission is fulfilled when they set other people to fighting, and abuse them if they come off second best.
They know how the thing ought to be done, but will not impart their knowledge by that most efficient means of instruction — example.
A more cowardly and bloodthirsty set of curs, from Lincoln down to Lane, than the Black Republican leaders in Washington, cannot be found on the face of the earth.
If they know the meaning of sensibility or shame, they would go home and hide themselves from public observation, instead of presuming to thrust themselves upon the notice of mankind, and presuming to censure the only men who have encountered peril, and to whom they are indebted for the rescue of their Government and themselves from complete destruction.
Their West Point Generals have not only had all their own inclinations to push forward if they could, but a reputation to gain, and all the incentives of military ambition.
Whenever they have permitted themselves to be pushed "right on," as Trumbull has it, and surrendered their own judgement to the outside pressure, the results have been the most bloody and disastrous defeats of the whole war.--Such were the battles of Manassas and Fredericksburg, and equally ruinous would have been every other Federal reverse if the military counsels of the Lincolns and Trumbulls had always been in the ascendant.

If the best Federal Generals of West Point have almost uniformly been defeated in this war it is not the fault of their military education, but of other causes, which the radicals of the United States Senate seem incapable of comprehending.--Trumbull & Co. do not seem to remember that it has been West Point against West Point, and that if the West Point leaders of the North have been defeated, it has been West Point Generals who have beaten them.
If the Northern graduates of that institution have not had the intellect and aptitude for war of the Southern graduates that is the misfortune of the North, but not the fault of the institution.
Besides the superiority of the Southern Generals is the superiority of the Southern soldiers, trained to the use of arms from their youth, and animated by the defence of their homes, their firesides, and the most glorious cause that ever called heroes to the field.
Above and more than all these is the manifest interposition in be half of the South of that Supreme Governor who rules the destinies of war and peace, and shapes the ends of men and nations, roughen them as they will.
The infidel mind of the North may scoff at such a solution of the mysterious confounding of their subtle devices, and the ignominious and continued failures of their colossal efforts to subjugate a people having not one-third their numbers or resources; but there are closer links between heaven and earth than are dreamt of in their philosophy, and the time may come when they will be on this point, as well as on sundry others, wiser, if not sadder men.

div3.p: Arrest the Deserters — The usual reward of $33 will be paid for the arrest and delivery to me, or to the officer in command of Castle Thunder Richmond city, of the following deserters from Company "A," 8th Regiment Louisiana Volunteers:

list.item:
1. Private Jas Boyd, a native of Ireland, about 32 years of age, red hair and beard, ruddy complexion, marked by the small pox, somewhat over 6 feet in height, and a teamster by occupation.
He is supposed to have joined a Virginia cavalry company.
2. Private Jno H. Cummins, a native of New York State, 21 years old light hair, no beard, fair complexion, blue eyes, about 5 feet 7 inches high, and a painter by trade.
3. Private Patrick Donohoe, a native of Ireland, about 37 years old, light black hair, ruddy complexion, quick of speech and motion, about 5 feet 5½ inches high and a gardener by trade.
4. Private Patrick Fitzgerald, a native of Ireland, near 40 years of age, black hair and beard slightly bald, black eyes, about 5 feet 8 or 9 inches high, and a day laborer.

5. Private Wm Reagan a native of New York State 30 years old, auburn hair, hazel eyes, stout built, some 5 feet 7 inches high, and a blacksmith by trade.
He deserted in the early part of last June, and is supposed to be in Richmond city, as I lately received a notice from Capt West, one of the Quartermasters of that city, that he had paid him $17158 as pay, bounty, and clothing money.
I will add $20 for Reagan's arrest, thus making the reward in his case $50.

div3.head: Commissioner's Sale of Land, slaves and other property, in the county of Hanover.
div3.p:
--Pursuant to a decree of Hanover County Court, entered on the 27th January, 1863, I shall offer for sale to the highest hidden at public auction, at the residence of the late Robert Anderson, near Old Church, in the county of Hanover, on Friday, the 17th day of February, 1863, a tract of land called "Parson's," lying about three or four miles from the Old Church, containing about one hundred acres. Also, sixteen likely Slaves, consisting of men, women, and children.
Also, all the Farming Implements and Household and Kitchen Furniture now in the possession of Mrs. Mary F. Anderson.

Terms.--For the slaves and perishable property cash will be required.
For the land, one-third cash, and the balance upon a credit of one and two years, with interest from the day of sale; or all cash, at the option of the purchaser.
If credit be given bond and good personal security will be required, and the title retained until the purchase money is all paid.
The taxes for 1863 to be paid by the purchaser.
